results.title: La Femme En Bleu = the Woman in Blue
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a famous musician, shares his time between his work and Aurelie, his lover. He becomes fascinated by a beautiful stranger, all dressed in blue, he saw only once and uses all his resources and connections to try and find her again.

Credits: Producer, Andre Genoves ; director, Michel Deville ; writers, Michel Deville, Francois Boyer, Leo L. Fuchs ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Bela Bartok, Franz Schubert.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Lea Massari, Michel Aumont, Simone Simon, Genevieve Fontanel.

results.title: Le Bonheur = Happiness
results.brief_description:
Anarchist Philippe Lutcher vows to kill anyone who represents ‘the establishment’. He ends up shooting idolised music-hall singer Clara Stuart in full view of her audience. The singer escapes death and the two get to know each other, eventually falling in love. At the trial, Clara offers to testify in favour of Philippe, but he refuses, determined to become a martyr to his cause.

Credits: Director, Marcel L’Herbier ; photography, Harry Stradling ; music, Billy Colson ; technical collaboration, Jean Dreville.
Cast: Gaby Morlay, Charles Boyer, Paulette Dubost, Michel Simon, Jean Toulout.

results.title: Une Affaire D'hommes = a Man's Affair
results.creator_credit: Nicolas Ribowski and Albina du Boisrouvray
results.brief_description:
Servolle is a police inspector and Faguet is a real estate dealer who become good friends because of their shared love of bicycling. Servolle is investigating a mysterious series of murders of women. The fourth victim happens to be Lalie, a woman Faguet introduced to the cycling group as his wife.

Credits: Producer, Albina du Boisrouvray ; director, Nicolas Ribowski ; writer, Georges Conchon ; photography, Jean-Paul Schwarz ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Claude Brasseur, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Jean Carmet, Eva Darlan, Beatrice Camurat.

results.title: Les Visiteurs du Soir = the Devil's Envoys
results.brief_description:
The film is based on the 15th century French legend, wherein the Devil, disturbed by the encroaching forces of Good, sends his envoys to Earth to drive the citizens to despair. Dominique and Gilles appear at the court of Baron Hugues disguised as troubadours on the day Hugues celebrates the engagement of his daughter Anne to Renaud. Dominique seduces the Baron and persuades him to kill Renaud during a tournament. But Gilles and Anne fall in love. Furious to see his scheme thwarted by true love, the devil himself decides to intervene. Note: The antisemitic laws of the Vichy regime made it illegal for Trauner and Kosma (regular members of Carne’s crew) to work in the film industry. Their work on this film is uncredited. Francois Chaumette, Simone Signoret, Alain Resnais and Jean-Pierre Mocky appear as extras.

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Laroche ; photography, Roger Hubert ; music, Joseph Kosma, Maurice Thiriet ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner, Georges Wakhevitch, Leon Barsacq.
Cast: Arletty, Alain Cuny, Marie Dea, Jules Berry, Fernand Ledoux, Marcel Herrand, Roger Blin, Jean d’Yd.

results.title: Le Trou = the Hole
results.brief_description:
Claude Gaspard is sent to jail for the attempted murder of his wife. He must share his cell with four other inmates: Roland, Manu, Monseigneur and Jo. The four have a plan to escape by digging a hole under their cell to connect with the sewers. Annoyed by Claude’s sudden arrival, they, albeit reluctantly, agree to share their plan with him. And so, Claude becomes a reluctant accomplice. Becker, in his last film before his death in 1960 (aged 54), seemed to be taking a new direction by using non-professional actors and a more austere camera style. With only natural noises as effects in the soundtrack, he builds a meticulously detailed account of the characters’ life in a small space and the preparations for escape. Jose Giovanni, who wrote the screenplay based on his own prison experience, appears at the beginning of the film. “To hear him tell it, Jose Giovanni never set out to become a writer, or embraced it as a vocation. His focus upon the realities of criminal life was never a social crusade. He wrote ‘Le Trou’, he says, with only one reader in mind: the lawyer Stephen Hecquet to whom the work is dedicated. It was Hecquet who sent the manuscript to a publisher in 1957. Its almost immediate sale to the cinema seemed equally fortuitous: director Jacques Becker had saved a newspaper clipping about the Sante prison break. When the book appeared he summoned the still jittery ex-con to a story meeting … at the home of Yves Montand and Simone Signoret.(…) When you are in jail, Jose Giovanni says, and a new person comes into your cell, whether it is a guard or a prisoner, you have to learn how to size them up with a single glance. This is a skill that is very useful later on when dealing with producers.” Reference: David Chute. ‘Jose Giovanni’. Online. http://www.geocities.com/Tokyo/Island/3102/jose.htm. See also: Robert Bresson’s ‘A man escaped’.

Credits: Producer, Georges Charlot ; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Jacques Becker, Jose Giovanni ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Jean Wiener.
Cast: Jean Keraudy, Marc Michel, Raymond Meunier, Michel Constantin, Philippe Leroy, Catherine Spaak, Eddy Rasimi, Andre Bervil, Jean-Paul Coquelin, Dominique Zardi.

results.title: Miquette et Sa Mere = Miquette and Her Mother
results.brief_description:
Miquette aspires to be an actress. She runs off with a nobleman who promises to make her a star. When Miquette’s mother searches for her wandering daughter, she finds the girl working with a ragtag touring company. The mother takes a job with the troupe to keep the lecherous nobleman away from Miquette. The film works best as a portrait of a provincial theatre in the 19th century.

Credits: Producer, Paul Joly ; director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writer, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Albert Lasry ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Bourvil, Daniele Delorme, Mireille Perrey, Saturnin Fabre, Pauline Carton, Paul Barge, Leonce Corne, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Olivier Hussenot, Philippe Nicaud, Pierre Olaf, Maurice Schutz, Louis Seigner.

results.creator_credit: Pierre Jourdan, Daniele Gegauff and Stephane Tchalgadjieff
results.brief_description:
This version of Verdi’s ‘Aida’ was recorded at the antique theatre of Orange (France). The stage direction is by Sandro Segui, decors by Pier-Luigi Pizi and choreography by Jacques Garnier. The Orchestra ‘Lirico di Torino’ is conducted by Thomas Schippers.

results.title: Qui? = Who?
results.brief_description:
A car rides off a cliff. The female passenger survives the ordeal, her male companion, the driver does not. The brother of the dead man takes the young woman back to his place. Although he suspects her to have something to do with his brother’s death, he is inexplicably attracted to her. The police recovers the dead body and for a while the suspicions a laid to rest. But the ‘dead man’ reappears not long after 

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Leonard Keigel ; writers, Leonard Keigel, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Maurice Ronet, Simone Bach, Jacques Duby, Gabriele Tinti.

results.title: Pile Ou Face = Heads or Tails
results.brief_description:
Edouard Morlaix’s wife dies after falling through a window. Inspector Baroni is convinced she was pushed by Morlaix who wanted to be free to run away with his mistress. Baroni starts harrassing Morlaix in the hope to have him break down and admit to the murder.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cravenne ; director, Robert Enrico ; writers, Robert Enrico, Michel Audiard, Marcel Jullian ; photography, Didier Tarot ; music, Lino Leonardi.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Michel Serrault, Dorothee, Pierre Arditi, Andre Falcon, Fred Personne, Jean Desailly.
